story.title: Marcus and the Apocalypse - Episode 5
story.storyDescription: When a nuclear weapon hits Manhattan, Marcus escapes. But can he survive in the violent, chaotic, refugee-glutted suburbs?
story.creator: web-uploader

author.bio: Emmy Laybourne is the author of the Monument 14 trilogy, which tells the story of fourteen kids trapped in a superstore while civilization collapses. Her new series, Berserker, is about a family of Norwegian teenagers with ancient Viking superpowers.

story.prePaywallNotification: Will Marcus and his friends escape the deadly bomb’s fallout? Read the conclusion of MARCUS AND THE APOCALYPSE.
story.postPaywallNotification: Will Marcus ever see Gabi again??! Read the conclusion of MARCUS AND THE APOCALYPSE.
story.authorPromoDescription: Emmy Laybourne is the author of the Monument 14 trilogy, which tells the story of fourteen kids trapped in a superstore while civilization collapses. Her new series, Berserker, is about a family of Norwegian teenagers with ancient Viking superpowers.

messages.text: Marcus runs to Shawn. He’s been knocked backwards by the shot.
He lays with his legs splayed out.
His lips are tainted black.
Is he…is he…
He’s dead.
Oh my God!
Gabi sinks to the ground.
Marcus takes her in his arms.
You saved me. You did it to save me.
Marcus, we need to go.
We need to get on that ATV and go, you and me.
But what about Luke? We can’t just leave him.
I think…I think we should. I really do. It’s getting crazy out here.
What if the infected people catch up with us?
What if they’re in front of us, like this guy was?
Look, we got the bandages. Let’s wrap up Luke’s leg.
And I’ll tell my uncle what’s happened and see what he says.
Marcus and Gabi return to Luke.
Oh God. I thought you guys left me.
Don’t cry, man. We got bandages. We’re gonna fix you up.
Where’s Shawn?
He’s not doing so good.
Where is he?
He tried to shoot Marcus.
Oh man.
Stop crying, Luke! Just stop it!
Marcus quickly updates his uncle via text.
You need to go. The ATV can probably hold your weight plus one other.
Take Gabi and go.
I can’t leave Luke. He can’t even walk.
This is about survival, son. You need to man up here.
Man up? Man up to leave someone to die?
No. That’s not the kind of man I am.
Hold up, now. Don’t make a rash decision.
Marcus sorts through all four backpacks and condenses them into two.
He hands one to Gabi.
You’re gonna take the ATV and head for the border.
It’s only another 15 miles.
You can make it in a couple hours.
What? No. No! I’m not going without you.
Yes you are.
I’ll bring Luke and we’ll see you there.
I can’t do this alone, Marcus!
Yes you can.
Don’t stop for anybody.
For any reason.
Gabi embraces Marcus.
She kisses him on the mouth.
Then she whispers in his ear:
If you have to leave him to stay alive, you’ll do it, right?
We’ll meet you across the border.
Gabi shoulders the backpack and stalks off toward the ATV.
She doesn’t look back.
Come on, Luke. We gotta get going.
All right. Thanks…thanks for not leaving me, Marcus.
Oh man, I’m gonna throw up. It hurts.
Lean on me as much as you need.
The boys walk through the forest.
Marcus supports Luke.
Every step is agony for Luke.
I’m so thirsty.
Here’s the last of the water.
You sure?
Yeah, take it.
Jesus, why you gotta be so heavy, Luke?
I’m sorry.
I’m kidding, man.
No. I’m sorry about everything. How I was a jerk. I was scared.
I AM scared. Right now.
I’m scared too. But we’re gonna make it.
I don’t think I can…
We just gotta keep on walking, Luke.
Luke lands a step wrong and screams in pain. He falls to the ground.
No! No, come on, man.
Just leave me. I’m so tired.
Stop it Luke. Come on! Get up.
Marcus whips his head around.
He’s pretty sure there are people in the woods near them.
It’s no good. We’re going too slow. The infected—
Alright — new plan. We’re going to the highway.
But they’ll get us.
Or we’ll get them. Maybe I’ll…I’ll steal a car or something. Like you and Shawn were gonna do.
I can’t do it.
Come on, I didn’t bring you this far to leave you in the woods to die.
Get up!
Luke struggles to his feet.
Marcus half drags him through the woods to the side of the highway.
As they draw near, they hear the sound of an Army soldier speaking over a megaphone.
This is a checkpoint.
We are checking for signs of infection.
Roll down your windows.
Remain in your cars.
Keep your hands in full sight.
Marcus hauls Luke up the embankment to the highway.
There is a blockade set up about 100 yards down the road.
Behind it, lines of cars are stuck for miles back.
Army trucks and ambulances are waiting on the other side of the checkpoint.
Some of the trucks have barred windows and gates.
Marcus can see infected people protesting and thrashing behind the bars.
Marcus drags Luke, who is only barely conscious right now, toward the blockade.
You! By the woods! Stay where you are!
Do not move! Put your hands up!
Don’t shoot us! We need help!
Please help my friend! He’s been shot.
Marcus has his hands up.
Luke is slumped on the ground.
Two Army reservists hurry over.
Open your mouth!
Marcus opens his mouth to show he’s not infected.
I’m clean! I’m clean!
What about your friend?
He’s not infected, just passed out. He got shot in the leg.
These kids are clear. We need a stretcher!
The reservist goes to pat Marcus on the shoulder. Marcus flinches.
It’s okay, kid. You’re safe now. You did good.
Two hours later, Marcus and Luke have been taken to the hospital at Stroudsburg.
Marcus sits on the floor in the waiting room, texting with Leon.
The room is jammed with anxious people.
I’m still having trouble getting through the blockade on this side of the state line.
I’m so sorry.
I should get through soon and then I’ll come right to the waiting room.
It’s okay, Uncle Leon. I’m safe.
Any word on your friend?
Not yet. They said he lost a lot of blood, but that the bullet didn’t hit any bone.
That’s a very good thing.
Sit tight, son, I’ll be there soon.
Uncle Leon, thanks.
I’m watching the news here and you were right.
The suburbs of NYC are a mess.
They’re swarming with infected people.
And fires are breaking out everywhere.
You were brave to leave when you did.
No word from my mom, right?
No word yet, son.
Marcus wipes a hand across his eyes.
He’s been praying he’ll get word from his mother, but reality is starting to set in.
But I know she would have been proud of what you’ve done.
Yeah.
They give you any food?
No, but I got the last candy out of a vending machine.
Marcus hears a commotion at the nurses’ station. It’s a girl’s voice.
Please, I just want to check.
Only the families of those being treated are allowed Miss!
I’m begging you, lady, please. I just know my friend is in there.
All right, honey, but don’t tell anyone I let you in.
Gabi appears in the doorway to the waiting room.
Her tear-stained face scans the crowd.
Marcus stands.
Gabi!
The two fly into each other’s arms.
I knew you’d make it.
Same for you! You were all right?
It was easy. I just had to get to that checkpoint.
If I’d known, I never would have left you.
We could have carried him together—
Doesn’t matter. We all made it.
Luke? Is he—
He’s gonna be fine.
Gabi puts her hands on either side of Marcus’s face and brings him in for a long, full kiss.
Marcus wraps her in his arms and holds her close.
I am so damn glad to see you.
Me too.
After a moment, Gabi pulls back.
Marcus, am I dreaming or do you taste like Skittles?
I got the last bag. But I saved some for you…
She kisses him again instead.
What do we do now?
We’re gonna wait to see if Luke can leave.
Then we’ll meet up with my Uncle Leon and he’ll take us to his place.
The two of them sit back down on the floor together, leaning against the wall.
Marcus kisses Gabi on the head. He smiles.
I guess you’re feeling pretty good about yourself.
Nah. I’m just glad you’re safe.
Okay then, give me that candy. I’m starving.
It’s all yours, Gabi.
